'''Ronald "Ronnie" Robertson''' (born September 25, 1937 in [[Brackenridge, Pennsylvania]]; died February 4, 2000 in [[Fountain Valley, California]]) was an [[United States|American]] [[Figure skating|figure skater]] who was best known for his [[figure skating spins|spinning]] ability. He won the silver medal at the [[1956 Winter Olympics]] and twice won the silver at the [[World Figure Skating Championships]]. He retired from skating after the 1956 U.S. Championships, where he was nearly disqualified after he was accused by the German Figure Skating Federation for excessive expenses on a European tour. His father, Albert Robertson, a naval architect, accused [[Hayes Alan Jenkins|Hayes Jenkins]] for trying to disqualify his son.<ref>[http://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1499&dat=19560317&id=zQMkAAAAIBAJ&sjid=kSUEAAAAIBAJ&pg=2985,4179269 The Milwaukee Journal<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> After a huge fight with the U.S. Figure Skating Federation, Robertson was not disqualified after he lost to Jenkins and retired from competitive figure skating and signed a two-year contract with the [[Ice Capades]] for $100,000.<ref name="Richard Goldstein">{{cite news| url=http://www.nytimes.com/2000/02/17/sports/ronnie-robertson-62-a-skater-who-entertained-with-his-spins.html?pagewanted=1 | work=The New York Times | title=Ronnie Robertson, 62, a Skater Who Entertained With His Spins | first=Richard | last=Goldstein | date=February 17, 2000 | accessdate=May 22, 2010}}</ref>
In the 1950s, he had a close personal and sexual relationship with [[Tab Hunter]],<ref name="autobio">{{cite book |last=Hunter |first=Tab |authorlink=Tab Hunter |coauthors=Eddie Muller |title=Tab Hunter Confidential: The Making of a Movie Star |year=2005 |publisher=Algonquin Books |location= |isbn=1565125487 }}</ref><ref>[http://www.outsmartmagazine.com/cms-this_issue/200511--Fab+Tab.html OutSmartMagazine.com<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> who also helped fund his amateur career.<ref name="autobio" /> Robertson was coached by [[Gustave Lussi]].<ref name="autobio" />
Robertson's skating career was also well known on [[television]]. He appeared on the ''[[Ed Sullivan Show]]'' in 1957, and his fast forward upright spin was described as being "faster than an electric fan." He also appeared on ''[[The Mickey Mouse Club]]'' that year.
Ronnie Robertson died on February 4, 2000 at a hospital in [[Fountain Valley, California|Fountain Valley]], [[California]] from complications of [[pneumonia]].<ref name="Richard Goldstein"/>
